question.question-text: Why does the student go to see the professor?

answer-list.answer-text: To tell the professor that he is getting married
To find out when the research project is due

answer-text.exp: To get permission to postpone the project due date

answer-list.answer-text: To explain why he was late turning in the paper

question.explain-text: In the conversation, the student says we have that big research project due next month and I was wondering if it would be possible to…turn in the project late. From this, it can be determined that the student goes to see the professor to get permission to postpone the project due date. The third answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: What excuse does the student use?

answer-list.answer-text: He has an important family event to attend.
The due date for the project is too soon.
The project is much harder than he had expected.

question.explain-text: In the conversation, the student says I have a really good reason for missing school…and delaying the project. You see, my brother…he's getting married then. It's going to be a really big wedding and I'm going to be part of the wedding…so…I'll have to…miss a few days of school next month…for the wedding. From this, it can be determined that the excuse that the student uses is that he has an important family event to attend. The second answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: How does the professor seem to feel abut this?

answer-list.answer-text: Missing a few days of class for the wedding is OK.
Missing a few days of class for the wedding is not OK.
Delaying the research project is OK.
Delaying the research project is not OK.

question.explain-text: In the conversation, the professor says to the student your brother's wedding sounds like a good reason to miss a couple of days of school and I want you to get the project done now, get it done early, before the wedding. From this, it can be determined that the professor seems to feel that missing a few days of class for the wedding is OK and delaying the research project is not OK. The first and last answers are therefore the best answers to this question.

question.question-text: Which of the following might the professor say?

answer-text.exp: "You have plenty of time to complete the project before the wedding."

answer-list.answer-text: "That seems like a good reason to delay the project."
"I can't believe that the wedding is so soon."

question.explain-text: In the conversation, the student says I'd really appreciate it if I didn't have to finish the research project until after the wedding, and the professor reponds by saying but the wedding's not for another month from now. The professor's reponse implies that the professor thinks that the wedding is a long way away, so the professor would most likely say you have plenty of time to complete the project before the wedding. The first answer is therefore the best answer to the question.

answer-list.answer-text: I'm not really doing you a big favor, but I'm telling you it is.
I'm sure you don't believe this because you never believe what I say.
It certainly seems like a big favor, but it's not.
You're not going to like this now, but you'll appreciate it later.

question.explain-text: In the conversation, the professor says listen, I'm going to do you a big favor, though you might not believe right now that it actually is a big favor. I want you to get the project done now, get it done early, before the wedding. That way, you won't have it hanging over your head during the wedding. From this, it can be determined that the professor means you're not going to like this now, but you'll appreciate it later. The last answer is therefore the best answer to this question.
